transcripts.text: I want to talk to you about your brand new book, The Victorians, 12 Titans Who Forged Britain.  I must also ask you about, of course, the two big bits of news at the moment, not only, of course, the Tory leadership, but also the arrival of Donald Trump in the country.  35 minutes ago, due to touchdown at nine o'clock, Air Force One, it turns out, does arrive on time.  And he's already left in Marine One.  Just before he landed, though, he'd hit back at Sadiq Khan, the London mayor, who'd been rather critical.  of Donald Trump, a quite extraordinary language, I thought, in the Observer newspaper yesterday, in which he referred to Donald Trump as being like the fascists of the 20th century.  Donald Trump has retorted with Sadiq Khan, who by all accounts has done a terrible job as Mayor of London, has been foolishly nasty to the visiting President of the United States, by far the most important ally of the United Kingdom.  He's a stone-cold loser who should focus on crime in London.  not me he said he can't reminds me very much of our very dumb and incompetent mayor of new york city de blasio who's also done a terrible job only half his height he adds.  in any event i look forward to being a great friend to united kingdom.  i'm looking very much forward to my visit.  landing now your response.

Well, I think it's perfectly reasonable, the President of the United States.  I think what the Mayor of London says is deeply disgraceful, that the fascists of the 1930s massacred millions of people, and Mr.  Trump is the democratically elected president of our closest ally.  I think that Mr.  Khan demeans his office, demeans the nation.  what he has said is quite wrong and deeply improper.  so i think for the president to hit back and say that he's a failed mayor of london which is true with spiraling knife crime deeply congested roads a general incompetence in city hall is fair enough.  so i'm backing mr trump in this route.
um do you think we should be rolling out the red carpet though for this man?

Yes, of course we should.  He is our closest ally.  The security of the United Kingdom is closely tied in with our friendship with the United States.  We're commemorating D-Day, when American lives were lost, sacrificed to save freedom in Europe and to save freedom in the United Kingdom.  We should be thanking him for what his country has done in the past and for the relationship we need in the future.

Is this very much then about the office of the presidency and about the country and our shared history together, rather than about basically rolling out the red carpet for Donald J. Trump, the apprentice star, owner of Trump Towers,  etc.?

It is always about the office.  And that's the key thing.  That's why we welcomed the president of China.  Now, we are commemorating the 30th anniversary of Tiananmen Square, when hundreds, possibly thousands of Chinese people calling for freedom were massacred.  But the real politique of it is that we have to welcome Chinese presidents.  And that is how the world works.  President Trump... It is not responsible for this type of evil.  He is a close ally and essential through his nation to our security.  Of course we should be rolling about the red carpet.  It should be of the deepest red and the finest hue.

Well, one of the reasons why a lot of people want us to cozy up with the United States, of course, is after, if and when, leaving the European Union, we want a free trade deal with the United States.  A lot of people are concerned, though.  Chlorinated chicken has become the big bogeyman.  about selling off the NHS to American health care providers.  Do you have any concerns about that?

Do you eat salad?  I have to.  I don't eat salad.  I think salad's absolutely disgusting.  But most salads sold in the UK, a lot of salads sold in the UK, is chlorine washed.  This stuff about chlorine is completely absurd.  It kills bacteria and means fewer people get salmonella.
I had some lovely chicken wings in New York a couple of years ago.

Most of us have gone to the US and eaten chicken.  The trick in there, it's American standards are extremely high and that's worth remembering.  It's all sort of cheap anti-Americanism.  In terms of the NHS, there is no trade deal that would stop the NHS being free at the point of use.  That is a matter of British law and will not be changed by free trade deals.

OK.  And what do you think about Donald Trump's endorsement of Boris Johnson?  He's the candidate for the Tory leadership that you've been openly backing and have done for some time before there was even a Tory leadership contest to think of.  Just a twinkle in Theresa May's eye.  Would you think that an endorsement from Donald Trump, he's a good guy alongside Nigel Farage, will help Boris Johnson with the Tory party faithful and particularly with Tory MPs?

Well, I think the President of the United States has been careful to remain within reasonable bounds.  So he says he thinks Boris is a good guy.  He hasn't said that Boris should be the next leader of the Conservative Party.  And I think that's right and I think that's tactful.  It's not as bad as Obama when he came over here telling us we'd be at the back of the queue, which was a direct interference in our democratic process.  But, yes, I think it is important that whoever our prime minister is has a working relationship with the president of the United States.  It is the most important international relationship from this country's point of view.  And that Boris can have from day one a good relationship with President Trump is good news.

Let's talk about your book, The Victorians, 12 Titans Who Forged Britain.  Many people have referred to you over the years as the member for the 18th century, so this is a book looking into the future for you.
That's right, this is a modern update on my general world view, yes.
Why did you decide to write this book?  And also, a small point, how do you have the time?
That's a very good question.  I write quite quickly, I suppose, is the answer.
But you've got six children and you've got a full-time job as a...

Well, one of the chapters was the encouragement of my eldest son.  He wanted the chapter on W.G.  Grace, which I much enjoyed writing and found Grace a fascinating figure and a very important one.  How did I decide to write the book?  Well, I share a birthday with Queen Victoria.  She was born on 24th of May, 1819, and I came along 150 years later.  So I've always had an interest in her.  Had I been a girl, I would have been called Victoria.  So from childhood, I've been interested in Queen Victoria and her reign.  And in this current... environment politically we aren't seeing the big figures who make great decisions and when you look back at the victorian era it's stuffed full of great figures.  indeed it would have been easier to have many times the number of people i've got in that book.  the difficulty was who to exclude And I think there's a lot we can learn from that.

Well, a lot of this is celebrating the past.  A lot of the time now we talk about our past, we seem to be denigrating it.  We seem to be ashamed of our colonial past.  So at the time when Victoria, you know, was it the sun never set on the British Empire.  But now we're supposed to be ashamed of that.  Is this trying to sort of slightly rewrite that modern take on history?

Well, it's a reminder that you can genuinely do good in the world.  So take Sleeman, who puts down Thuggee in India.  Thuggee is a religious cult around the goddess Kali that murders travellers.  Sleeman puts this down, and he does it by being a good administrator and through legal processes, so you can travel safely in India.  This is a good thing to do.  The moral relativists would say, oh, no, if people have their practices, they should carry on with them.  But actually the Victorians recognised that moral relativism wasn't enough.  Some things are wrong.  Napier in Sindh tries to put an end to suti, the practice of widow burning.  Again, burning widows is wrong and wrong.  We shouldn't be taken in by moral relativism.  We should look back with pride at our history and the amazing things we did and actually the ability to advance civilization, which we achieved.
I have to be honest with you.  An awful lot of the reviews have been quite negative about your book.
Absolutely terrible.
I didn't like to put it like that.  I was being kind.
My friend Simon Herford said it was written by a baboon.  So I hope you will assure your listeners that there is no baboon sitting in front of you in the studio.
Absolutely not.  I would say you write as you speak very eloquently.  Do you think a lot of these reviews were, shall we say, politically motivated?
No, no, I think it's much more fun as a reviewer to write a critical review than a friendly one, and taking potshots of politicians is a national sport, so I'd make no objection.

I've been asked to write reviews over the years, and I always think, well, if I like the book, it's going to be a really boring review, just saying, oh, it's a really good book, just read the book.  And I say, if it's negative, then I don't want to waste my time finishing a book.  I think's rubbish.

That's absolutely true.  One doesn't want to read a book that one doesn't enjoy.  And it's one of those things that Dr Johnson maintained he never read a book to the end.  He just read the bits that he thought were interesting.  And I've always thought that's a sensible approach, but not one I've ever properly managed.

In terms of getting to the end, let's talk about getting to the end of this Tory leadership contest.  It hasn't even officially started.  The Prime Minister leaves on Friday, resigns on Friday.  Well, she'll stay in number 10 while this process continues.  The official nominations open and close next Monday the 10th.  You're going to be one of the nominators for...
